Content 1: \gll Or-op i koora ik-e-mik neeke ekap-o-k. | \gls descend-SS.SEQ 1p.UNM house be-PA-1p there.CF come-PA-3s | \glt `It descended and came to the house/building where we were.'

Knowledge Point: Because of the structural and even intonational similarity, it is sometimes difficult to tell if a particular \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{rc}} is restrictive or non-restrictive. When the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{antnp}} is a proper noun or when it includes a first or second person singular pronoun, the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{rc}} is usually non-restrictive \REF{ex:8:x1567}, \REF{ex:8:x1568}:
Content 1: \gll Bang=ke ekap-o-k, Ponkila aaw-o-k nain. | \gls Bang=CF come-PA-3s Ponkila get-PA-3s that1 | \glt `Bang came, (he) who married Ponkila.'
Content 2: \gll Yo nena owowa moma marew nain miatin-i-yem. | \gls 1s.UNM 2s.GEN village taro no(ne) that1 dislike-NP-PR.1s | \glt `I don't like your village, which doesn't have taro.'

Knowledge Point: The proximate demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fain} `this' can also function as a relative marker in the non-restrictive \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{rc}}s but not in restrictive ones \REF{ex:8:x1536}:
Content 1: \gll Nomokowa unowa fan-e-mik, Simbine ekap-omak-e-mik fain. | \gls 2s/p.brother many here-PA-1/3p Simbine come-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p this | \glt `Your many (clan) brothers are here, these Simbine people who came.'

Knowledge Point: When the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{antnp}} is a pronoun other than first or second singular, the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{rc}} may be either restrictive or non-restrictive \REF{ex:8:x1570}.
Content 1: \gll I mua yiam ikur, fikera ikiw-e-mik nain. | \gls 1p.UNM man 1p.REFL five kunai.grass go-PA-1/3p that1 | \glt `There were five of us men who went to the kunai grass (= pig-hunting).' Or: `We were five men, who went pig-hunting.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: In the use of quote formulas, Mauwake is much freer than Papuan languages in general. A direct quotation in Mauwake is often preceded or followed by one of the utterance verbs. The verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- `say/think' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naak}- `say/tell' are almost exclusively used after quotes. Enclosing a quote between two utterance verbs is not frequent \REF{ex:8:x1571}:
Content 1: \gll Ne ona mua pun \textbf{ma-e-k}, ``Eka maneka nain=ke iwa-mi ifakim-o-k,'' \textbf{na-e-k}. | \gls ADD 3s.GEN man also say-PA-3s river big that1=CF come-SS.SIM kill-PA-3s say-PA-3s | \glt `Her husband also said, ``The big river came and killed her,'' he said.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Most commonly, only a speech verb precedes the quote \REF{ex:8:x1578}, \REF{ex:8:x1579}:
Content 1: \gll Panewowa=ke \textbf{ma-e-k}, ``Yo nia maak-emkun opaimika efa fien-a-man.'' | \gls old=CF say-PA-3s 1s.UNM 2p.ACC tell-2/3p.DS talk 1s.ACC disobey-PA-2p | \glt `The old (woman) said, ``When I told you, you disobeyed me.'' '
Content 2: \gll Iiw-ep wiipa muuka nain wia \textbf{maak-e-k}, ``Auwa maa p-ikiw-om-aka. | \gls dish.out-SS.SEQ daughter son that1 3p.ACC tell-PA-3s 1s/p.father food BPX-go-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2p | \glt `She dished out (the food) and told the children, ``Take the food to father.''{}'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: A single utterance verb \REF{ex:8:x1580} or a whole quote-closing clause \REF{ex:8:x1583} may follow the quote. A quote-closing clause has to be used when the quotation consists of several sentences.
Content 1: \gll ``No bom fain=iw mera kuum-e,'' \textbf{naak-e-mik}. | \gls 2s.UNM bomb this=INST fish burn-IMP.2s tell-PA-1/3p | \glt ` ``Blast fish with this bomb,'' they told him.'
Content 2: \gll ``I muuka marew a, wiipa marew a,'' \textbf{naap} \textbf{wia} \textbf{maak-e-k}. | \gls 1p.UNM son no(ne) ah daughter no(ne) ah thus 3p.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt ` ``We have no son, we have no daughter,'' he told them like that.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: In narratives where there are several exchanges between the participants, it is possible to leave out the utterance verb \REF{ex:8:x1581}, \REF{ex:8:x1582} and even the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} referring to the speaker of the utterance \REF{ex:8:x1581}, if the speaker is clear enough from the context. A good speaker creates variety in the text by utilizing all these different possibilities.
Content 1: \gll Ne onak=ke \textbf{{\O}}, ``A, ifera feeke un-eka.'' Ne wi maak-e-mik, ``Wia, i oro-or-op un-i-yan.'' ``A, neeke-r=iw un-eka.'' ``Weetak, i oro-ora-i-yan.'' | \gls ADD 3s/p.mother {\O} Ah, salt.water here.CF fetch(water)-IMP.2p ADD 3p.UNM tell-PA-1/3p No 1p.UNM RDP-descend-SS.SEQ fetch-NP-FU.1p Ah there.CF-{\O}=LIM fetch-IMP.2p no 1p.UNM RDP-descend-NP-FU.1p | \glt `And their mother (said), ``Ah, fetch the sea water (from) here.'' But they told her, ``No, we'll go down (to the deep sea) and fetch it.'' ``Ah, fetch it right there.'' ``No, we'll go down a long way.'' '
Content 2: \gll ``Mauwa ar-e-n, amia=iya nenar-e-mik=i?'' Sarak=ke \textbf{{\O}}.\hspace{-1mm} | \gls what become-PA-2s bow=COM shoot.you-PA-1/3p=QM Sarak=CF {\O} | \glt ```What happened to you, did they shoot you with a gun?'' Sarak (asked).'
Content 3: \gll Ne onak=ke \textbf{{\O}}, ``A, ifera feeke un-eka.'' Ne wi maak-e-mik, ``Wia, i oro-or-op un-i-yan.'' ``A, neeke-r=iw un-eka.'' ``Weetak, i oro-ora-i-yan.'' | \gls ADD 3s/p.mother {\O} Ah, salt.water here.CF fetch(water)-IMP.2p ADD 3p.UNM tell-PA-1/3p No 1p.UNM RDP-descend-SS.SEQ fetch-NP-FU.1p Ah there.CF-{\O}=LIM fetch-IMP.2p no 1p.UNM RDP-descend-NP-FU.1p | \glt `And their mother (said), ``Ah, fetch the sea water (from) here.'' But they told her, ``No, we'll go down (to the deep sea) and fetch it.'' ``Ah, fetch it right there.'' ``No, we'll go down a long way.'' '

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Most indirect quotes in Mauwake are syntactically identical to direct quotes. There is an intonational difference: the indirect quote is part of the intonation contour of the main clause, rather than having a contour of its own as a direct quote has. The quote is almost always followed by the utterance verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- `say, think' \REF{ex:8:x1585}; but it is also possible for the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ma}- `say' to precede it, in which case both the utterance verb and the quote have their own intonation contour \REF{ex:8:x1587}.\footnote{In Amele, the absence of the speech verb before the quote is the main criterion for indirect speech \citep[14]{Roberts1987}. In Mauwake, this cannot be used as a criterion, as the occurrence of speech verbs with direct quotes varies so much.} An indirect quote is never enclosed between two utterance verbs.
Content 1: \gll Aria, Kalina, Amerika ekap-e-mik na-i-mik. | \gls alright Kalina America come-PA-1/3p say-NP-PR.1/3p | \glt `Alright, Kalina, they say that the Americans have come.'
Content 2: \gll Ma-e-m, nena owowa=pa ik-o-n. | \gls say-PA-1s 2s.GEN village=LOC be-PA-2s | \glt `I said (to her\textsubscript{i}) that you\textsubscript{j} are in your own village.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: As direct quotes behave independently of their matrix clauses, they often have a separate deictic centre. But indirect quotes vary in this respect. Deictic elements, which get part or all of their interpretation from the situational context, are often the same in indirect quotes as they would be in direct quotes \REF{ex:8:x1584}, \REF{ex:8:x1280}:
Content 1: \gll Aite=ke manina yook-e na-eya o ook-e. | \gls 1s/p.mother=CF garden follow.me-IMP.2s say-2/3s.DS 3s.UNM follow.her-IMP.2s | \glt `When mother tells you to follow her to the garden, follow her.'
Content 2: \gll Ni Krais yena teeria efar ik-eka na-ep nia far-eya ona teeria wiar ik-e-man. | \gls 2p.UNM Christ 1s.GEN family 1s.DAT be-IMP.2p say-SS.SEQ 2p.ACC call-2/3s.DS 3s.GEN family 3.DAT be-PA-2p | \glt `Christ called you to be his family and (now) you are his family.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: But the deictic centre may also shift partly or completely towards that of the matrix clause. When this happens, the pronouns are the easiest to change, next the adverbs. In \REF{ex:8:x1586} a second person pronoun has replaced the proper name or third person pronoun that would have been used in a direct quote.
Content 1: \gll Sarak oo, Amerika ekap-ep Ulingan nan ik-e-mik, \textbf{nefa} ikum-i-mik na-i-mik oo. | \gls Sarak INTJ America come-SS.SEQ Ulingan there be-PA-1/3p 2s.ACC wonder.about-NP-PR.1/3p say-NP-PR.1/3p INTJ | \glt `Sarak! The Americans have come and are in Ulingan and they say that they are wondering where you are!'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When reported by the addressee of the example clause \REF{ex:8:x1281}, only the pronoun in the reported clause \REF{ex:8:x1282} is different:
Content 1: \gll No owowa ikiw-ep buk nain sesek-om-e. | \gls 2s.UNM village go-SS.SEQ book that1 send-BEN-BNFY1.IMP.2s | \glt `When you go to the village, send the book to me.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yo} owowa \textbf{ikiw-ep} buk nain sesek-om-e efa na-e-k. | \gls 1s.UNM village go-SS.SEQ book that1 send-BEN-BNFY1.IMP.2s 1s.ACC say-PA-3s | \glt `He told me to send that book to him (lit: me) when I would go to the village.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: The verbs are most resistant to deictic shift. In \REF{ex:8:x1264}, even though the verb root changes, it still retains the tense and person marking of the direct quote \REF{ex:8:x1265}. Both the temporal adverb and the pronoun are shifted to reflect the deictic centre of the matrix clause.
Content 1: \gll Uurika nefar ikiw-i-nen. | \gls tomorrow 2s.DAT go-NP-FU.1s | \glt `Tomorrow I'll come (lit: go) to you.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ikoka} \textbf{efar} \textbf{ekap-}i-nen na-e-k na weetak. | \gls Later(today) 1s.DAT come-NP-FU.1s say-PA-3s but no | \glt `He said that he would come to me today, but he hasn't.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Below in \REF{ex:8:x1266} also the person suffix is changed from that in \REF{ex:8:x1267} to reflect the situation of the new speech act participants.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Ona owowa=pa ik-ua. | \gls 3s.GEN village=LOC be-PA.3s | \glt `She is in her own village.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- `say, think' indicates thinking, the complement clause is usually an indirect quote rather than a direct one \REF{ex:8:x1588}, \REF{ex:8:x1589}.
Content 1: \gll Muuka ifera me enim-i-non na-ep me uruf-a-m. | \gls boy salt.water not drink-NP-FU.3s think-SS.SEQ not look-PA-1s | \glt `Thinking that the boy wouldn't drown I didn't watch him.'
Content 2: \gll Mua pepena=ke menat=ke ek-i-ya na-ep menat ora-i-nan. | \gls man inexperienced=CF tide=CF go-NP-PR.3s think-SS.SEQ tide descend-NP-FU.2s | \glt `An inexperienced man will think that the tide is going down and will go to fish at low tide.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Indirect non-polar questions are similar to the corresponding direct questions apart from possible adjustments to deictic elements \REF{ex:8:x1592}, \REF{ex:8:x1590}.
Content 1: \gll Wi uf-ow(a) epa kaaneke ik-ua na-e-k. | \gls 3p.UNM dance-NMZ place where.CF be-PA.3s say-PA-3s | \glt `He asked where their dancing place was.'
Content 2: \gll O ikoka sesa kamenap aaw-i-non na-e-k. | \gls 3s.UNM later price what.like get-NP-FU.3s say-PA-3s | \glt `He asked what kind of wages he would get later.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Polar questions, when indirect, have to be alternative questions \REF{ex:8:x1591}. The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naep} may be deleted, when the indirect question is sentence-final \REF{ex:8:x1593}.
Content 1: \gll Beel-al-i-non=i kamenion na-ep uruf-am-ik-ua. | \gls rotten-INCH-NP-FU.3s=QM or.what think-SS.SEQ see-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `He was watching (thinking) whether it would rot or what would happen.'
Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: In Mauwake, the future, imperative, counterfactual and nominalized forms of the main verb are possible in the complement clause. In desiderative clauses, the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na-} `say/think' is always in the medial same-subject sequential form \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naep}; in purpose clauses, other forms are possible as well. Historically, there probably always used to be a clause with a finite verb following the clause expressing intention or desire \REF{ex:8:x367}; synchronically the finite clause is often missing \REF{ex:8:x368}, especially when the verb would be the same as in the complement.
Content 1: \gll Niena maa enim-u na-ep iiw-eka. | \gls 2p.GEN food eat-IMP.1d say-SS.SEQ dish.out-IMP.2p | \glt `If you want/intend to eat food, dish it out (yourselves).'
Content 2: \gll Yo opora gelemuta=ko ma-i-nen na-ep. | \gls 1s.UNM talk little=NF say-NPS-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ | \glt `I want to tell a little story.' Or: `I'm going to tell a little story.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: The main verb in the complement clause is either marked for first person\footnote{Purpose clauses may use other person forms as well (\sectref{sec:8.3.2.1.4}).} or is nominalized. Mauwake uses the future \REF{ex:8:x368} or imperative form \REF{ex:8:x369} of the main verb for intention or a clear/certain wish, and the counterfactual form for a wish that has less potential to be realized. The latter is also the most polite form to use, if the wish indicates a request \REF{ex:8:x370}.
Content 1: \gll Yo opora gelemuta=ko ma-i-nen na-ep. | \gls 1s.UNM talk little=NF say-NPS-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ | \glt `I want to tell a little story.' Or: `I'm going to tell a little story.'
Content 2: \gll Haussik p-ek-u na-ep miiw-aasa nop-a-mik. | \gls aidpost \TEXTSC{BPx}-go-IMP.1d say-SS.SEQ land-canoe search-PA-1/3p | \glt `We/they wanted to take her to the aidpost and looked for a vehicle.'
Content 3: \gll Yo=ko wia uruf-ek-a-m na-ep. | \gls 1s.UNM=NF 3p.ACC see-CNTF-PA-1s say-SS.SEQ | \glt `I would like to see them.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: The nominalized form is mostly used in complement clauses that can also be interpreted as purpose clauses. In ``pure'' desiderative clauses it is practical to use the nominalized form especially if the first person marking in the verb might make it harder to process the meaning \REF{ex:8:x1610}:
Content 1: \gll Ne o uruf-owa ne maa en-owa asip-owa na-ep=na eliw asip-uk. | \gls ADD 3s.UNM see-NMZ ADD food eat-NMZ help-NMZ say-SS.SEQ=TP well help-IMP.3p | \glt `And if they want to see him and help him with food, let them help him.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Purpose is both conceptually close and structurally similar to desiderative, and in Mauwake many of the desiderative clauses can be interpreted as purpose clauses. This is particularly so when the main verb is in the nominalized form \REF{ex:8:x371}, \REF{ex:8:x345}. But a truly desiderative clause even with an action nominal is never right-dislocated, whereas a purpose clause \REF{ex:8:x372} often is. The nominalized form in the main verb is common:
Content 1: \gll Weniwa=pa en-owa na-ep uuw-i-mik. | \gls famine=LOC eat-NMZ say-SS.SEQ work-NP-PR.1/3p | \glt `We work in order to (be able to) eat during the time of hunger.'
Content 2: \gll Wi Amerika wiam=iya irak-owa na-ep ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM America 3p=COM fight-NMZ say/think-SS.SEQ go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went to fight with the Americans.'
Content 3: \gll Ona siowa ikos manina ikiw-e-mik, pika on-owa na-ep. | \gls 3s.GEN dog with garden go-PA-1/3p fence make-NMZ say-SS.SEQ | \glt `He went to the garden with his dog, in order to make a fence.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Future and imperative forms are also used in the purpose clause. When the subject in the purpose clause is the same as the subject of the utterance verb and the main clause, the first person future form is used for singular \REF{ex:8:x1614}, \REF{ex:8:x1616} and first person dual imperative for plural \REF{ex:8:x1620}.
Content 1: \gll Nain nefa maak-i-nen na-ep yo ep-a-m. | \gls that1 2s.ACC tell-NP-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ 1s.UNM come-PA-1s | \glt `I came to tell you that.'
Content 2: \gll No owora sesenar-i-nen na-ep Kainantu fofa ikiw-ep neeke aaw-i-nan. | \gls 2s.UNM betelnut buy-NP-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ Kainantu market go-SS.SEQ there.CF get-NPS-FU.2s | \glt `To buy betelnut you will (need to) go to Kainantu marker and get it \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{there}}.'
Content 3: \gll Ne haussik p-ek-u na-ep miiw-aasa nop-a-mik. | \gls ADD aidpost BPX-go-IMP.1d say-SS.SEQ land-canoe search-PA-1/3p | \glt `And they searched for a truck (in order) to take him to the aidpost.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When the subject of the verb in the main clause differs from that of the purpose clause, the verb inside the purpose clause has to be in the imperative \REF{ex:8:x1062}--\REF{ex:8:x1627}. The whole purpose clause is structurally like a direct quote of the ``inner speech'' verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naep}, so there is no deictic shift of the kind that may take place in indirect quotes.
Content 1: \gll Me yiar-uk na-ep koka=pa ik-e-mik. | \gls not shoot.us-IMP.3p say-SS.SEQ jungle=LOC be-PA-1/3s | \glt `We stayed in the jungle so that they would not shoot us.'
Content 2: \gll Ne wi popor-ar-urum-ep ik-ok ifana muutiw wu-am-ika-i-kuan, mua unuma wia miim-u na-ep. | \gls ADD 3p.UNM silent-INCH-DISTR/A-SS.SEQ be-SS ear only put-SS.SIM-be-NP-FU.3p man name 3p.ACC hear-IMP.1d say-SS.SEQ | \glt `And they all will be quiet and listen carefully in order to hear the men's names.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: There is no raising of negation from the subordinate to the main clause \REF{ex:8:x1623}.
Content 1: \gll Yo me pina=pa nia wu-ek-a-m na-ep ma-i-yem. | \gls 1s.UNM not guilt=LOC 2p.ACC put-CNTF-PA-1s say-SS.SEQ say-NP-PR.1s | \glt `I am not saying (this) to put guilt on you.' (=I am saying this, but not in order to put guilt on you.)

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: A purpose clause does not always have the auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naep}. A clause with just a nominalized verb is used especially with the directional verbs \REF{ex:8:x1659}, \REF{ex:8:x1658}:
Content 1: \gll Yo yena emeria aaw-owa urup-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.GEN woman take-NMZ ascend-PA-1s | \glt `I came up to take my wife.'
Content 2: \gll Bogia ikiw-e-mik, opaimika aakun-owa. | \gls Bogia go-PA-1/3p talk talk-NMZ | \glt `We went to Bogia to talk.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: A clause with a nominalized verb plus a clause-final distal-1 demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} 'that' is also possible, but less common \REF{ex:8:x1633}, \REF{ex:8:x1634}. I have not observed a functional difference between the different purpose structures.
Content 1: \gll Tunde=pa maa muutitik uruf-owa nain soomar-e-mik. | \gls Tuesday=LOC thing all.kinds see-NMZ that1 walk-PA-1/3p | \glt `On Tuesday we walked to see all kinds of things.'
Content 2: \gll Ifemak-ep nomona iinan=pa wua-i-nan, ikoka ifera me p-ikiw-owa nain. | \gls press-SS.SEQ stone on.top=LOC put-NP-FU.2s later sea not BPX-go-NMZ that1 | \glt `You press it down and put stones on top ( or: put it on top of stones/corals) so that the sea would not later take it away.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Instead of using a verbal construction with the verb `see' for conative modality -- expressing the attempt to do something -- which \citet[152]{Foley1986} claims as almost universal for Papuan languages, Mauwake makes use of a structure where the desiderative is followed by the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{on-} `do' as the verb in its reference clause \REF{ex:8:x373}. Usan uses an identical construction for the same purpose \citep[258]{Reesink1987}.
Content 1: \gll Mukuna umuk-u na-ep on-a-mik=na me pepek. | \gls fire extinguish-IMP.1d say-SS.SEQ do-PA-1/3p=TP not enough | \glt `We tried to extinguish the fire but were not able to.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When this structure is used, it is implied that somehow or other the effort fails \REF{ex:8:x374}, \REF{ex:8:x1606}:
Content 1: \gll Emeria aruf-i-nen na-ep on-am-ik-eya op-a-mik. | \gls woman hit-NP-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ do-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS hold-PA-1/3p | \glt `When he was trying to hit the woman, they grabbed him.'
Content 2: \gll Wia uruf-ek-a-m na-ep on-a-k on-a-k weetak, o me wia uruf-a-k. | \gls 3p.ACC see-CNTF-PA-1s say-SS.SEQ do-PA-3s do-PA-3s no 3s.UNM not 3p.ACC see-PA-3s | \glt `He tried and tried to see them, but no, he didn't see them.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: The conative structure is not used when the effort is successful \REF{ex:8:x375}, and also when the `trying' is not so much an effort to do something as experimenting \REF{ex:8:x376}. In these cases the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akim-} `try' is used, which is neutral as to the outcome. It requires a nominalized verb in the complement clause.
Content 1: \gll Aasa keraw-owa akim-ap akim-ap amis-ar-i-nan. | \gls canoe carve-NMZ try-SS.SEQ try-SS.SEQ knowledge-INCH-NP-FU.2s | \glt `After trying and trying to carve a canoe, you will know (how to do it).'
Content 2: \gll Weria op-ap wiinar-owa nain akim-am-ik-e. | \gls planting.stick hold-SS.SEQ make.planting.holes-NMZ that1 try-SS.SIM-be-IMP.2s | \glt `Keep trying/learning to make planting holes with the planting stick.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Another complementation strategy for utterance verbs is a clause with a nominalized verb. It is used when the event expressed in the clause is regarded as potential, rather than an actual activity or a fact. The following example has two levels of complementation, as the verb in the nominalized complement also takes a nominalized complement \REF{ex:8:x1599}:
Content 1: \gll I yiena miiw-aasa muf-owa ikiw-owa na-em-ik-omkun o ar-e-k. | \gls 1p.UNM 1p.GEN land-canoe pull-NMZ go-NMZ say-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS 3s.UNM become-PA-3s | \glt `While we were talking about our going to fetch a vehicle, she died (lit: became).'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: The same strategy is used with the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- `tell' when it is used in the sense of ordering someone to do something \REF{ex:8:x1630}:
Content 1: \gll Emar, no muut fain uf-owa nefa maak-e-m. | \gls friend 2s.UNM only this dance-NMZ 2s.ACC tell-PA-1s | \glt `Friend, I told you to dance only this.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: It was mentioned above (\sectref{sec:8.2.3.4}) that the chaining structure is used with perception verbs in Mauwake as the main complementation strategy for perception verbs, when the complement is an activity \REF{ex:8:x1512} or event \REF{ex:8:x1600}. These are not genuine complement clauses, as they are not embedded in the main clause, but they perform the same function as regular complement clauses do.
Content 1: \gll Mukuruna wu-am-ika-iwkin i miim-a-mik. | \gls noise put-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS 1p.UNM hear-PA-1/3p | \glt `We heard you making (the) noise.'
Content 2: \gll Urema maneka um-ep ika-eya uruf-a-mik. | \gls bandicoot big die-SS.SEQ be-2/3s.DS see-PA-1/3p | \glt `They saw the big bandicoot dead (=having died).'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: A regular complement clause is only used with perception verbs about a past activity, when the complement clause reports a fact rather than an activity \REF{ex:8:x1628}, \REF{ex:8:x1629}.

Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When a perception verb takes an indirect question as a complement, it has to be a regular complement clause \REF{ex:8:x1631}:

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: The verbs for knowing, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{amisar}- and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{paayar}- together cover the cognitive area of knowing facts and skills, coming to realize, and understanding. When the complement clause indicates contents of factual knowledge, it is usually a regular complement clause \REF{ex:8:x1602}.
Content 1: \gll O kaanek aaw-ep p-ekap-om-a-mik nain me amis-ar-e-k. | \gls 3s. where.CF get-SS.SEQ BPX-come-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p that1 not knowledge-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `He didn't know where they got it from and brought to him.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: It seems that a clause with a nominalized verb is also used as a ``fact'' complement but only when it refers to pre-knowledge of an event \REF{ex:8:x1605}. It could also be understood as a ``potential'' type complement, in which case it is natural that it uses this complementation strategy. This requires more investigation.
Content 1: \gll O ikiw-owa nain amis-ar-e-n=i? | \gls 3s.UNM go-NMZ that1 knowledge-INCH-PA-2s=QM | \glt `Did you know about his going?'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When the complement is about knowing a skill, the verb in the complement clause is in nominalized form, or a medial clause is used \REF{ex:8:x1603}, \REF{ex:8:x1849}:
Content 1: \gll Nain on-owa (nain) me amis-ar-e-m. | \gls that1 do-NMZ that1 not knowledge-INCH-PA-1s | \glt `I don't know how to do that.'
Content 2: \gll Sawiter inera on-ap amis-ar-e-k. | \gls Sawiter basket make-SS.SEQ knowledge-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `Sawiter knows how to make baskets.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: When the complement indicates lack of some experience, a construction with a medial clause is used. In this case, the main clause is in the negative, and the scope of the negation has to extend to the medial clause \REF{ex:8:x1604}:
Content 1: \gll Owora en-ep me paayar-e-m. | \gls betelnut eat-SS.SEQ not understand-PA-1s | \glt `I'm not used to eating betelnut.' Or: `I don't know how to eat betelnut.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: Both types of a nominalized clause (ยง\sectref{sec:5.7.1}, \ref{sec:5.7.2}) may be used as subjects in verbless clauses, even though this function for complement clauses is not common. A clause with a nominalized verb is used when the activity is potential \REF{ex:8:x1636}, \REF{ex:8:x1637}.
Content 1: \gll Maa wiar ikum aaw-owa eliwa=ki? | \gls thing 3.DAT illicitly take-NMZ good=CF.QM | \glt `Is stealing from others good?'
Content 2: \gll Maa eneka me en-owa maa marew. | \gls thing tooth not eat-NMZ thing no(ne) | \glt `Not eating meat is all right.'

Subsection: Complement clauses and other complementation strategies \label{sec:8.3.2
Knowledge Point: A regular complement clause with a finite verb is used when the activity is considered a fact \REF{ex:8:x1639}:
Content 1: \gll Ni unuma niam p-ir-i-man nain eliw(a) marew. | \gls 2p.UNM name 2p.REFL BPX-ascend-NP-PR.2p that1 good no(ne) | \glt `That you praise yourselves (lit: lift up your own name) is not good.'

Knowledge Point: The presence of the distal-1 demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' indicates the pragmatic difference between the temporal clauses and those medial clauses that may get a temporal interpretation: the temporal clauses are presented as given information \REF{ex:8:x1540}--\REF{ex:8:x1624}, whereas the medial clauses usually present new information \REF{ex:8:x1632}, except when they occur in tail-head constructions.
Content 1: \gll Ni ifa nia keraw-i-ya nain sira kamenap on-i-man? | \gls 2p.UNM snake 2p.ACC bite-NP-PA.3s that1 custom what.like do-NP-PR.2p | \glt `When a snake bites you, what do you do?'
Content 2: \gll Yo napum-ar-e-m nain eneka maay-ar-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM sick-INCH-PA-1s that1 tooth long-INCH-PA-1s | \glt `When I got sick, I became hungry for meat (lit: my teeth got long).'
Content 3: \gll Yo napum-ar-ep eneka maay-ar-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM sick-INCH-SS.SEQ tooth long-INCH-PA-1s | \glt `I got sick and became hungry for meat.'

Knowledge Point: Locative adverbial clauses use a clause-final deictic locative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nan} \REF{ex:8:x1621} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{neeke} \REF{ex:8:x1626} `there' instead of the demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that'. Note that in \REF{ex:8:x1621} the locative noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{manina} `garden' is not a relative \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}}; if there were one, that would be \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{epa} `place' immediately preceding \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nan} `there'.
Content 1: \gll I naap ikiw-ep yiena manina on-a-mik nan ik-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM thus go-SS.SEQ 1p.GEN garden make-PA-1p there be-PA-1p | \glt `We went there and stayed where we had made our gardens.'
Content 2: \gll Luuwa niir-i-mik neeke soomar-e-mik. | \gls ball play-NP-PR.1/3p there.CF walk-PA-1/3p | \glt `We walked (to) where they play football.'
Content 3: \gll I naap ikiw-ep yiena manina on-a-mik nan ik-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM thus go-SS.SEQ 1p.GEN garden make-PA-1p there be-PA-1p | \glt `We went there and stayed where we had made our gardens.'

Knowledge Point: The following example is actually a locative relative clause, since it has a relative \textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{np}} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kame} `side' that has a function in both clauses \REF{ex:8:x1638}:
Content 1: \gll No in-i-n kame nan urup-ep tepak iw-a-mik. | \gls 2s.UNM sleep-NP-PR.2s side there ascend-SS.SEQ inside go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They climbed up on the side where you sleep and went inside.'

Knowledge Point: The topic marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} (\sectref{sec:3.12.7.1}) marks an adversative clause when the main clause cancels an expectation, either expressed in the text or assumed to be in the hearer's mind. Because of this, this construction is used when some effort is frustrated \REF{ex:8:x729}, or when there is a strong element of surprise \REF{ex:8:x730} in the main clause.
Content 1: \gll Mukuna nain umuk-a-mik=\textbf{na} me pepek. | \gls fire that1 quench-PA-1/3p=TP not able | \glt `They tried to quench the fire, but couldn't.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:8:x1393}, what the boys expect to see is a crocodile, but it turns out to be a turtle.
Content 1: \gll Takir(a) oko=ke pon muneka wu-ek-a-m na-ep urup-em-ika-eya uruf-ap tuar=ke na-ep alu-emi baurar-e-k. Takir(a) unowa ekap-ep uruf-a-mik=\textbf{na} pon=ke, ne unow=iya op-ap kirip-a-mik. | \gls boy other=CF turtle egg put-CNTF-PA-1s say-SS.SEQ ascend-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS see-SS.SEQ crocodile=CF say-SS.SEQ shout-SS.SIM flee-PA-3s boy many come-SS.SEQ see-PA-1/3p=TP turtle=CF ADD many=COM hold-SS.SEQ turn-PA-1/3p | \glt `A boy saw a turtle coming up (to the beach) to lay eggs and thought it was a crocodile, and shouted and fled. Many boys came and saw/looked, but it was a turtle, and they all together grabbed and turned it.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:8:x1397}, a man talks to his son whom he wanted and expected to be a good person:
Content 1: \gll Aakisa yo nefa uruf-i-yem=\textbf{na} no mua eliw marew. | \gls now 1s.UNM 2s.ACC look-NP-PR.1s=TP 2s.UNM man good no(ne) | \glt `I now look at you but you are not a good man.'

Knowledge Point: Because these clauses express a cancellation or frustration of an expectation, a negator commonly follows as the first element in the main clause, and often the negator is the only element left of the main clause, as in \REF{ex:8:x1398}.
Content 1: \gll Marasin wu-om-a-mik=\textbf{na} weetak. | \gls medicine put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p=TP no | \glt `They injected medicine in him, but no (it had no effect).'

Knowledge Point: In \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{imaginative conditional clauses}}, the verb in both the protasis and the apodosis is in the counterfactual mood, which is marked by the suffix -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ek}. The conditional/topic marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} is always present. The same form is used for semantically counterfactual and hypothetical conditionals. The counterfactual interpretation \REF{ex:8:x1645} is more common, but especially if there is a reference to present \REF{ex:8:x1646} or future time \REF{ex:8:x1647}, it forces a hypothetical interpretation.
Content 1: \gll Yo Sek haussik ikiw-\textbf{ek}-a-m=\textbf{na} miiw-aasa=pa uroma yaki-\textbf{ek}-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM Sek hospital go-CNTF-PA-1s=TP land-canoe=LOC stomach wash-CNTF-PA-1s | \glt `If I had gone to the Sek hospital, I would have given birth in the truck.'
Content 2: \gll Yena aamun aakisa uruf-\textbf{ek}-a-m=\textbf{na} kemel-\textbf{ek}-a-m. | \gls 1s.GEN 1s/p.younger.sibling now see-CNTF-PA-1s=TP be.happy-CNTF-PA-1s | \glt `If I saw my younger brother now, I would be happy.'
Content 3: \gll Morauta iimar-ow(a) mua ik-\textbf{ek}-a-k=\textbf{na}, uurika ikiw-ep maak-\textbf{ek}-a-mik. | \gls Morauta stand.up-NMZ man be-CNTF-PA-3s=TP tomorrow go-SS.SEQ tell-CNTF-PA-1/3p | \glt `If Morauta were the leader, we would go and talk to him tomorrow.'

Knowledge Point: Usually the context determines the interpretation, but without a clear context the sentence may be ambiguous \REF{ex:8:x1648}:
Content 1: \gll Inasin napuma ik-\textbf{ek}-a-k=\textbf{na} sariar-\textbf{ek}-a-k. | \gls spirit/white.man sickness be-CNTF-PA-3s=TP recover-CNTF-PA-3s | \glt `If it were the white man's sickness\footnote{This is contrasted with owow napuma `village sickness', caused by sorcery.} he would recover.' Or: `If it had been the white man's sickness, he would have recovered.'

Knowledge Point: When the predictive conditional is a statement, the verb in both the protasis and in the apodosis is usually in the future tense \REF{ex:8:x1652}.
Content 1: \gll No oram mokok=iw \textbf{ika-i-nan=na} ikoka mua lebuma \textbf{ika}\textbf{-}\textbf{i}\textbf{-}\textbf{nan}. | \gls 2s.UNM just eye=INST be-NP-FU.2s=TP later man lazy be-NP-FU.2s | \glt `If you just watch with your eyes (without joining the work) you will be(come) a lazy man.'

Knowledge Point: The protasis may have a medial verb form if the condition is likely to be fulfilled \REF{ex:8:x1654}, or when the protasis consists of two or more clauses that are in a medial-final relationship \REF{ex:8:x1653}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria \textbf{sesenar-ek-a-m} \textbf{na-ep=na} waaya ten erup naap wienak-i-non. | \gls woman buy-CNTF-PA-1s say/think-SS.SEQ=TP pig ten two thus feed.him-NP-FU.3s | \glt `If/when he wants to buy a wife, he will give him (=the bride's father) twenty or so pigs.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Predictive conditionals allow right-dislocation of the protasis, but it is uncommon \REF{ex:8:x1662}:
Content 1: \gll Owora fain aite panewowa onak-e, ekap-ep \textbf{kerer-eya=na}. | \gls betelnut this 1s/p.mother old feed-IMP.2s come-SS.SEQ arrive-2/3s.DS=TP | \glt `Give these betelnuts to old mother to eat, if she comes and arrives here.'

Knowledge Point: In those instances where the conditional marker is attached to a predicate that is not originally a verb, the predicate needs to have medial verb marking \REF{ex:8:x1660}, \REF{ex:8:x1661} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.5}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Weetak-eya}\textbf{=na} weetak. | \gls no-2/3s.DS=TP no | \glt `If not, then not.'
Content 2: \gll Mauw-owa \textbf{manek-aya=na} yia maak-i-non. | \gls work-NMZ big-2/3s.DS=TP 1p.ACC tell-NP-FU.3s | \glt `If the work is big, he will tell us.'

Knowledge Point: When the apodosis is in the imperative, there is normally some expectation that the the condition is to be fulfilled. When the likelihood is high, the medial form is used in the protasis \REF{ex:8:x1650}, \REF{ex:8:x1649}. Present tense \REF{ex:8:x1651} and imperative \REF{ex:8:x1656} indicate less, and future tense \REF{ex:8:x1657} the least likelihood for the condition to be fulfilled.
Content 1: \gll Wia \textbf{uruf-ap=na} wia maak-e. | \gls 3p.ACC see-SS.SEQ=TP 3p.ACC tell-IMP.2s | \glt `If/when you see them, tell them.'
Content 2: \gll Maa mauwa nefa \textbf{maak-iwkin=na} opaimika miim-e. | \gls thing what 2s.ACC tell-2/3p.DS=TP talk listen-IMP.2s | \glt `Whatever they may tell you, listen to the talk.' (Lit: `If they tell you what(ever), listen to the talk.')
Content 3: \gll Koora pun naap: mua oko naareke koora \textbf{kua-i-ya=na} o asip-e. | \gls house also thus man other who.CF house build-NP-PR.3s=TP 3p.UNM help-IMP.2p | \glt `A house is like that too: if/when any man builds a house, help him.'
Content 4: \gll Ni kirip-owa \textbf{ika-inok}=\textbf{na} kirip-eka. | \gls 2p.UNM reply-NMZ be-IMP.3s=TP reply-IMP.2p | \glt `If you have something to reply, then reply.'
Content 5: \gll Wia \textbf{uruf-i-nan=na} wia maak-e. | \gls 3p.ACC see-NP-FU.2s=TP 3p.ACC tell-IMP.2s | \glt `If you (happen to) see them, tell them.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Reality conditional clauses}} are morpho-syntactically different from the other conditional clauses in that they are not marked with the topic marker. The protasis and apodosis are juxtaposed main clauses in future tense \REF{ex:8:x1644}, but this construction is mainly used to encode habitual or generic conditions. The protasis can never be right-dislocated, since it does not have the topic marker.
Content 1: \gll No inasin(a) unuma me unuf-i-nan, mua oko=ke waaya nain mik-ap nefar aaw-i-non. | \gls 2s.UNM spirit name not call-NP-FU.2s man other=CF pig that1 spear-SS.SEQ 2s.DAT take-NP-FU.3s | \glt `If you don't call the spirit name, another man will spear the pig and take it from you.'

Knowledge Point: If there are two protasis clauses, they may be juxtaposed without a connective \REF{ex:8:x1635} or joined with the pragmatic additive \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} \REF{ex:8:x1643}.
Content 1: \gll Nena kuuf-i-nan, parew-i-non, eliw perek-i-nan. | \gls 2s.GEN see-NP-FU.2s mature-NP-FU.3s well harvest-NP-FU.2s | \glt `If you see it yourself and it is matured you may harvest it.'
Content 2: \gll Yo um-i-nen ne yena emeria mua oko aaw-i-non, muuka onaiya me ikiw-i-non. | \gls 1s.UNM die-NP-FU.1s ADD 1s.GEN woman man other take-NP-FU.3s son with not go-NP-FU.3s | \glt `If I die and my wife takes another husband, she will not go (to him) with the son.'

Knowledge Point: When a sentence contains alternatives expressed by two sets of reality conditional constructions, these are joined by the pragmatic additive \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} \REF{ex:8:x1642}.
Content 1: \gll Yo auwa miiwa=pa mauw-i-nen, irak-owa marew, ne yo aite miiwa=pa mauw-i-nen, irak-owa ika-i-non. | \gls 1s 1s/p.father land=LOC work-NP-FU.1s fight-NMZ no(ne) ADD 1s 1s/p.moher land=LOC work-NP-fu.1s fight-NMZ be-NP-FU.3s | \glt `If I work on my father's land there is no fighting (over land), but if I work on my mother's land there will be fighting.'

Knowledge Point: The same construction can encode a simple coordinate relationship, but it is less common. In spoken text a slightly falling intonation at the end of the first clause indicates a coordinate sentence \REF{ex:8:x1850}.
Content 1: \gll Oko=ke pusun-emi feeke \textbf{ikiw}\textbf{-}\textbf{i}\textbf{-}\textbf{non}, a mua oko=ke \textbf{mik}\textbf{-}\textbf{i}\textbf{-}\textbf{non}. | \gls other=CF run.loose-SS.SIM here.CF go-NP-FU.3s ah man other=CF spear-NP-FU.3s | \glt `Another (pig) will run loose and run this way, ah, another man will spear it.'

Knowledge Point: Concessive clauses may look exactly like the predictive conditional clauses \REF{ex:8:x1655}. If the context is not clear enough, the phrase \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain pun} `that too' may be added between the protasis and the apodosis for clarification \REF{ex:8:x1430}.
Content 1: \gll Naapeya aara=ki e kasi=ke um-inok=na ni nain kema bagiw-ir-ap malaria sevis me wia iirar-eka. | \gls therefore hen=CF.QM or cat=CF die-IMP.3s=TP 2p.UNM that1 liver hatred-rise-SS.SEQ malaria service not 3p.ACC remove-IMP.2p | \glt `Therefore, (even) if hens or cats die, do not get angry and drive away the Malaria Service people.'
Content 2: \gll Naap yia ma-ikuan=na \textbf{nain} \textbf{pun} ni kekan-ep sira eliwa ook-eka. | \gls thus 1p.ACC say-FU.3p=TP that too 2p.UNM be.strong-SS.SEQ custom good follow-IMP.2p | \glt `Even if they talk about us like that, be strong and follow the good custom/ways.'

Knowledge Point: Subordinate clauses may also be coordinated with each other, although in normal speech the frequency of these constructions is low. The only subordinate clauses in the natural text data conjoined either by juxtaposition or with the additive \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} are relative clauses \REF{ex:8:x1381}, \REF{ex:8:x1382}. The distal demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain}, functioning as a relative marker, is attached to the end of each relative clause.
